abstract.t: This specification provides a framework for the use of strong authorization with OAuth 2.0. Mechanisms are specified for initiating an authorization session. New authorization grant types are defined that allow clients to obtain access tokens within the context of a strongly authorized session.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Strong authorization is a method of access control that grants access only after multiple factors of authentication and/or authorization have been presented. Authentication factors typically fall into the following categories: knowledge (something you know), possession (something you have), and inherence (something you are). Strong authorization factors include transaction confirmation and multi-party authorization.

OAuth 2.0 is an authorization framework that enables a third-party application to obtain limited access to a protected HTTP resource. In OAuth, those third-party applications are called clients; they access protected resources by presenting an access token to the HTTP resource. Access tokens are issued to clients by an authorization server with the (sometimes implicit) approval of the resource owner. These access tokens are typically obtained by exchanging an authorization grant, which represents the authorization granted by the resource owner (or by a privileged administrator).

This specification defines a general framework for the use of strong authorization within OAuth 2.0. It provides a mechanism for indicating when strong authorization is required. It also provides a generic mechanism for obtaining a strong authorization challenge. It defines additional extension grant types that allow strong authorization grants to be presented in order to obtain access tokens.
This use of strong authorization allows authorization servers to implement correspondingly strong authorization policies, including step-up authentication and transaction confirmation.

Authorization servers that implement support for resource owner password credentials can augment existing password infrastructure by requiring a strong second factor of authentication prior to issuing access tokens.

Transaction confirmation can be used to increase the level of assurance prior to issuing tokens for highly privileged operations, such as a bank withdrawl. For example, an end-user (resource owner) can grant an application (client) access to her account at a brokerage firm (resource server). The application is authorized to obtain real-time stock quotes as well as place orders, and is issued both an access token and refresh token. As a matter of policy, the access token can be used to obtain stock quotes and is valid for 24 hours. Every 24 hour period, the refresh token is used to obtain a new access token, so that access to stock quotes is uninterrupted. The access token can also be used to place an order, but is subject to more stringent security requirements. Using this extension, the refresh token can be used to initiate an authorization session which, once confirmed by the user, allows issuance of an access token that demonstrates strong authentication and has a limited lifetime.

section.title: Notational Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.name: Terminology
section.t: This specification also defines the following terms:

dl.dd: A challenge issued by an authorization server to a client requesting an additional authorization grant that is required in order to issue an access token.
A sequence of access token requests to the token endpoint, each presenting an authorization grant. The sequence MAY involve requests to additional endpoints, as needed by specific grant types.
A short lived token representing an authorization session, used to keep state during an authorization session.

section.name: Protocol Flow
section.t: The abstract OAuth 2.0 multi-factor authorization flow illustrated in describes the interaction between the resource owner, client, authorization server, and resource server and includes the following steps:

ol.li: The client requests authorization from the resource owner. The authorization request can be made directly to the resource owner (as shown), or indirectly via the authorization server as an intermediary.

The client receives an authorization grant, which is a credential representing the resource owner's authorization. The authorization grant type depends on the method used by the client to request authorization and the types supported by the authorization server.
The client requests an access token by authenticating with the authorization server and presenting the authorization grant.
The authorization server authenticates the client and validates the authorization grant, and if an additional authorization grant is required, issues an authorization challenge.
The client requests additional authorization from the resource owner. The authorization request is made directly to the resource owner.

The client receives an additional authorization grant. The authorization grant type depends on the method used by the client to request authorization and the types supported by the authorization server.
The client requests an access token by authenticating with the authorization server and presenting the additional authorization grant along with the MFA token received in the authorization challenge.
The authorization server authenticates the client and validates the authorization grant and MFA token, and if both are valid, issues an access token.
The client requests the protected resource from the resource server and authenticates by presenting the access token.
The resource server validates the access token, and if valid, serves the request.

section.name: Authorization Grants
section.t: An authorization grant is a credential representing the resource owner's authorization (to access its protected resources) used by the client to obtain an access token. This specification defines four grant types -- one-time password, out-of-band, and recovery code -- that can be used as additional authorization grants within an authorization session.

section.name: Protocol Endpoints
section.t: The multi-factor authorization process utilizes two authorization server endpoints (HTTP resources):

ul.li: Token endpoint - used by the client to exchange an authorization grant for an access token, typically with client authentication. This endpoint will be called multiple times within an authorization session.
Authorization challenge endpoint - used by the client to obtain an authorization challenge, the response to which can be used as an authorization grant.

section.t: Not every authorization grant type utilizes both endpoints. Extension grant types MAY define additional endpoints as needed.

section.name: Token Endpoint
section.t: The token endpoint is used by the client to obtain an access token by presenting its authorization grant or refresh token, as described in OAuth 2.0.

If the access token request is valid and authorized, the authorization server issues an access token and optional refresh token as described in OAuth 2.0. If the request failed client authentication or is invalid, the authorization server returns an error response as described in OAuth 2.0.
If the access token request is valid but not sufficiently authorized, the authorization server MAY issue an authorization challenge error response as as described in .

section.name: Authorization Challenge Error Response
section.t: An authorization challenge error response is a particular type of error response as defined in OAuth 2.0 where the error code is set to the following value:

dl.dd: The authorization grant is insufficiently authorized, but another access token request MAY succeed if an additional authorization grant is presented.

section.t: In addition to the response parameters defined in OAuth 2.0, the following parameters MUST be included in the response when the error code is set to "mfa_required":

dl.dd: MFA token value associated with the ongoing authorization session.

section.t: For example:

figure.artwork:
HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden Content-Type: application/json;charset=UTF-8 Cache-Control: no-store Pragma: no-cache
{ "error":"mfa_required", "mfa_token": "eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsImtpZCI6IjFlOWdkazcifQ.eyJpc3Mi OiJodHRwOi8vc2VydmVyLmV4YW1wbGUuY29tIiwic3ViIjoiMjQ4Mjg5NzYxMDA xIiwiYXVkIjpbImh0dHA6Ly9zZXJ2ZXIuZXhhbXBsZS5jb20vdG9rZW4iLCJodH RwOi8vc2VydmVyLmV4YW1wbGUuY29tL2F1dGhlbnRpY2F0b3JzIl0sIm1mYSI6W yJvdHAiLCJvb2IiXSwiZXhwIjoxMzExMjgxOTcwLCJpYXQiOjEzMTEyODA5NzB9 .IvjKKc54lHvAOCskyEUU8Ou_-8-oXKyFS5bbq-utZPA" }

section.name: Authorization Challenge Endpoint
section.t: The authorization challenge endpoint is used by the client to obtain an authorization challenge by presenting an MFA token. The client will typically interact directly with the resource owner to obtain an authorization grant, which is used as a response to the authorization challenge.
Use of the authorization challenge endpoint is OPTIONAL; if a client knows of a suitable authenticator through an out-of-band mechanism, it can obtain a strong authorization grant directly.

section.name: Authorization Challenge Request
section.t: The client makes a request to the authorization challenge endpoint by adding the following parameters using the "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" format with a character encoding of UTF-8 in the HTTP request entity-body:

dl.dd: REQUIRED. The MFA token received from the authorization server in the authorization challenge error response.
OPTIONAL. Array of authorization challenge type strings that the client supports, expressed as a list of space-delimited, case-insensitive strings.
OPTIONAL. The identifier of the authenticator to challenge. The authorization server MUST ensure that the authenticator is associated with the resource owner.
REQUIRED, if the client is not authenticating with the authorization server as described in OAuth 2.0.

section.t: If the client type is confidential or the client was issued client credentials (or assigned other authentication requirements), the client MUST authenticate with the authorization server as described in OAuth 2.0.
For example, the client makes the following HTTP request using transport-layer security (with extra line breaks for display purposes only):

figure.artwork:
POST /challenge HTTP/1.1 Host: server.example.com Authorization: Basic czZCaGRSa3F0MzpnWDFmQmF0M2JW Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
mfa_token=eyJhbGciOiJ...&challenge_type=otp%20oob

section.t: The authorization server MUST:

ul.li: require client authentication for confidential clients or for any client that was issued client credentials (or with other authentication requirements),
authenticate the client if client authentication is included,
ensure that the MFA token was issued to the authenticated confidential client, or if the client is public, ensure that the token was issued to "client_id" in the request,
verify that the MFA token is valid, and
restore the authorization session based on the state referenced by or encoded into the MFA token.

section.name: Authorization Challenge Response
section.t: If the authorization challenge request is valid and authorized, the authorization server selects an authorization challenge, the response to which would satisfy the authorization session, and constructs the response by adding the following parameters to the entity-body of the HTTP response using the "application/json" format with a 200 (OK) status code:

dl.dd: REQUIRED. The type of the authorization challenge issued. Value is case insensitive.

section.t: All additional parameters are specified by the authorization challenge type. This document defines the "otp" type in , the "oob" type in , and the "recovery-code" type in .
For example:

figure.artwork:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/json;charset=UTF-8 Cache-Control: no-store Pragma: no-cache
{ "challenge_type":"otp" }

section.t: If the authorization challenge request failed, the authorization server responds with an error response as described in OAuth 2.0.
In addition to the error codes defined in OAuth 2.0, the following error codes are specified for use in authorization challenge endpoint responses:

dl.dd: The requested authenticator does not exist or is not associated with the resource owner.
The provided MFA token is invalid, expired, revoked, or was issued to another client. The client MAY initiate a new authorization session.
The challenge types supported by the client are not supported by the authorization server or not available to the resource owner.
The resource owner is not associated with any authenticator. The authorization session MAY be continued by completing authenticator association.
The authorization server encountered an unexpected condition that prevented it from fulfilling the request.

The authorization server received an invalid response from an upstream server it accessed in attempting to fulfull the request. This typically occurs when challenging an OOB authenticator and the gateway is down, for example SMS.

section.title: OTP Credentials Grant
section.t: An one-time password is generated by an OTP device, which includes hardware devices as well as software-based OTP generators on devices such as mobile phones.

section.name: Authorization Challenge
section.t: If the authorization server requires an OTP credential as an authorization grant, it responds with an OTP authorization challenge containing the following parameters:

dl.dd: REQUIRED. Value MUST be set to "otp".

section.t: No additional parameters are specified for the OTP authorization challenge type.

section.title: User Interaction
section.t: After receiving an OTP challenge, the client prompts or otherwise interacts with the resource owner to obtain a one-time password generated by a device in the possession of the resource owner.

section.title: Access Token Request
section.t:
The client makes a request to the token endpoint by adding the following parameters using the "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" format per Appendix B with a character encoding of UTF-8 in the HTTP request entity-body:
REQUIRED. Value MUST be set to "http://auth0.com/oauth/grant-type/mfa-otp".
REQUIRED. The one-time password.
REQUIRED. The MFA token received when initiating the authorization session.
REQUIRED, if the client is not authenticating with the authorization server as described in Section 3.2.1 of .
If the client was issued client credentials (or assigned other authentication requirements), the client MUST authenticate with the authorization server as described in Section 3.2.1 of .

section.title: Access Token Response
section.t: If the access token request is valid and authorized, the authorization server issues an access token and optional refresh token as described in in Section 5.1 of . If the request failed client authentication or is invalid, the authorization server returns an error response as described in Section 5.2 of .

section.title: Out-of-Band Verification Code Grant
section.t: An out-of-band verification code is used to obtain authorization via an out-of-band authorization ceremony. Such ceremonys may include confirmation via an out-of-band authenticator or multi-party authorization.
An out-of-band authenticator is a device that can communicate securely with the authorization server over a secondary channel, such as SMS or push notification.
Multi-party authorization requires approval from a second authorized user, in addition to the resource owner, before an action is allowed to take place.
Out-of-band mechanisms are intentionally open-ended, to allow for flexibility in how authorization is obtained. The details of any out-out-band mechanism are beyond the scope of this specification.

section.name: Authorization Challenge
section.t:
The authorization server orchestrates an out-of-band authorization interaction, and responds with a challenge containing the following parameters:
REQUIRED. Value MUST be set to "oob".
REQUIRED. The out-of-band transaction code generated by the authorization server. The out-of-band transaction code MUST expire shortly after it is issued to mitigate the risk of leaks. A maximum out-of-band transaction code lifetime of 10 minutes is RECOMMENDED.
OPTIONAL. The method used to bind the out-of-band channel with the primary channel. The following methods are defined:
The resource owner should be prompted to enter a code received via an out-of-band authenticator.
OPTIONAL. The duration in seconds of the out-of-band transaction code lifetime.
OPTIONAL. The minimum amount of time in seconds that the client SHOULD wait between polling requests to the token endpoint.

section.title: User Interaction
section.t: After receiving an out-of-band challenge, the client prompts or otherwise interacts with the resource owner to inform them of the ongoing authorization ceremony. Any necessary action by the resource owner or other party will depend on the specific out-of-band mechanism.

For example, if confirmation is being obtained via an out-of-band authenticator, the resource owner will need to perform an authorization gesture on the device in her posession. If multi-party authorization is being performed, the resource owner will need to wait until the request is granted by a party with sufficient authorization rights.

section.title: Access Token Request
section.t:
The client makes a request to the token endpoint by adding the following parameters using the "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" format per Appendix B with a character encoding of UTF-8 in the HTTP request entity-body:
REQUIRED. Value MUST be set to "http://auth0.com/oauth/grant-type/mfa-oob".
REQUIRED. The out-of-band verification code.
REQUIRED, if the binding method of the out-of-band challenge is set to prompt.
REQUIRED. The MFA token received when initiating the authorization session.
REQUIRED, if the client is not authenticating with the authorization server as described in Section 3.2.1 of .
If the client was issued client credentials (or assigned other authentication requirements), the client MUST authenticate with the authorization server as described in Section 3.2.1 of .

section.title: Access Token Response
section.t: If the access token request is valid and authorized, the authorization server issues an access token and optional refresh token as described in in Section 5.1 of . If the request failed client authentication or is invalid, the authorization server returns an error response as described in Section 5.2 of .

In addition to the error codes defined in Section 5.2 of , the following error codes are specific for the out-of-band verification code grant:
The authorization request is still pending as the authorization ceremony has not yet completed. The client should repeat the Access Token Request to the token endpoint.
The client is polling too quickly and should back off at a reasonable rate.
The "oob_code" or "mfa_token" has expired. The client will need to initiate a new authorization session.
The resource owner or authorization server denied the request.

section.title: Recovery Code Grant
section.t: Recovery codes are a physical or electronic set of secrets shared between the resource owner and the authorization server. Recovery codes are typically used in the event another authenticator device is lost or malfunctions.

section.name: Authorization Challenge
section.t: If the authorization server requires a recovery code as an authorization grant, it responds with a recovery code authorization challenge containing the following parameters:

dl.dd: REQUIRED. Value MUST be set to "recovery-code".

section.t: No additional parameters are specified for the recovery code authorization challenge type.

section.title: User Interaction
section.t: A user typically signals to the client that they wish to enter a recovery flow after realizing that an authenticator device has been lost or is malfunctioning.

Upon receiving this signal from the user, the client prompts or otherwise interacts with the resource owner to obtain a recovery code. Such codes are typically already in the resource owner's posession, having been previously generated and delivered when enrolling an authenticator device.

section.title: Access Token Request
section.t:
The client makes a request to the token endpoint by adding the following parameters using the "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" format per Appendix B with a character encoding of UTF-8 in the HTTP request entity-body:
REQUIRED. Value MUST be set to "http://auth0.com/oauth/grant-type/mfa-recovery-code".
REQUIRED. The recovery code.
REQUIRED. The MFA token received when initiating the authorization session.
REQUIRED, if the client is not authenticating with the authorization server as described in Section 3.2.1 of .
If the client was issued client credentials (or assigned other authentication requirements), the client MUST authenticate with the authorization server as described in Section 3.2.1 of .

section.title: Access Token Response
section.t: If the access token request is valid and authorized, the authorization server issues an access token and optional refresh token as described in in Section 5.1 of . If the request failed client authentication or is invalid, the authorization server returns an error response as described in Section 5.2 of .

In addition to the parameters defined in Section 5.1 of , the following additional parameters are specific for the recovery code grant:
OPTIONAL. A newly issued recovery code, in which case the client MUST discard the old recovery code and replace it with the new recovery code.

section.title: Discovery Metadata
section.t: Support for the strong authorization flow MAY be declared in the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Server Metadata with the following metadata:
